subject: RE: [junit] Testing getXXX( ) and setXXX( ) methods
msgSnippet: ... Perhaps you re not saving as much time as you think, if you re writing tests for those methods that should never break. Consider a macro, instead, that
messageBody:
Quoting "Stevens, Timothy J. (LNG-MBC)" <timothy.j.stevens@...>:

> Nope... perfectly serious. I tend to copy and paste my getX() and
> setX() methods to save typing, then do search and replaces to set the
> variable names (lazy... or just efficiently using my time? you decide
> ;).

Perhaps you're not saving as much time as you think, if you're writing tests
for those methods that should never break.

Consider a macro, instead, that inflates the field into a getX() and setX()
method. That might be a less error-prone way to do it.

> Sometimes I goof and access/mutate the wrong thing. It happens, and my
> test
> cases have helped me to find my errors a few times.
>
> Plus, I just don't like idea of "Write JUnit test cases for all
> accessable methods... except for the really simple ones."

Well, "test everything that could possibly break" is a well-known, time-
honored, trusted maxim of XP. It was designed to deal with the fact that "you
can't test every case". That said, you should dislike it until you don't
dislike it anymore. Keep doing what you're doing.
